The Art of French Cookery

L’Art de la Cuisine Française
M. A. Carême  ·  Translated by W. Hall  ·  London, 1836
938 Recipes
8 Categories
560 Pages
1836 First English Edition

“The perfection of cookery depends entirely upon the choice of those meats and accessories which are requisite for making good broths, sauces, and entremets; and the sauces give a flavour to the ragouts and entrées.”

— M. A. Carême, The Art of French Cookery, 1836

The Author

Marie-Antoine Carême (1784–1833) was the founder of haute cuisine and the most celebrated chef of the Napoleonic era. Rising from poverty in Paris, he cooked for Talleyrand, Tsar Alexander I, the Prince Regent of England, and Baron de Rothschild. He systematised French cooking into the grand classical tradition that defined professional kitchens for a century.

This Volume

This English edition — translated by W. Hall and published in London in 1836 — draws together his major works: L’Art de la Cuisine Française, Le Pâtissier Royal Parisien, and Le Cuisinier Parisien. It covers the full classical kitchen: stocks, soups, fish, pastry, entrées, pièces montées, confectionery, and cold service.

The Collection

This digital edition presents 938 recipes across eight categories, drawn from the complete 560-page text. The collection spans restorative broths and elaborate court soups, grand fish dishes, delicate pastries, sculptural sugar pieces, and the full repertoire of cold entrées in aspic.
